6-2-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
6-2-1.RATIONALE: Hygiene has long-established links with public health, and the explicit reference to hygiene in the text of SDG target 6.2 represents increasing recognition of the importance of hygiene and its close links with sanitation. Hygiene is multi-faceted and can comprise many behaviours, including handwashing, menstrual hygiene and food hygiene. International consultations among WASH sector professionals identified handwashing with soap and water as a top priority in all settings, and also as a suitable indicator for national and global monitoring.
6-2-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on the number of people with a handwashing facility where water and soap or detergent and total population. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.
6-2-1.DATA_COMP:
Proportion of population with handwashing facility where water and soap or detergent are present divided by total population, expressed as percentage.

Proportion of population with handwashing facility where water and soap or detergent are present = Number of people with handwashing facility where water and soap or detergent are present / Total population ×100

3-7-1.SDG_GOAL: 3 Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-7-1.SDG_TARGET: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes
3-7-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 3.7.1 Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15-49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods
3-7-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
WHO defines the indicator proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15-49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfies with modern methods as the percentage of women of reproductive age (15-49 years) who desire either to have no (additional) children or to postpone the next child and who are currently using a modern method of contraception.

This indicator has two components i.e. contraceptive prevalence (any method and modern methods) and unmet need for family planning. The percentage of women who are currently using, or whose partner is currently using, at least one method of contraception, regardless of method use. Contraceptive methods are classified as either modern or traditional. Female and male sterilization, intra-uterine device (IUD), implant, injectable, oral contraceptive pills, condoms, vaginal barrier, lactation amenorrhea method (LAM), emergency contraception and other modern methods not reported separately falls under modern contraceptive methods.
3-7-1.SOURCE_TYPE: An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.
3-7-1.COLL_METHOD:
The sample for the Nepal MICS 2019 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas and seven provinces. The urban and rural areas within each province were identified as the main sampling strata. Kathmandu valley urban is included as a separate stratum as it’s characteristics differ from the rest. Each stratum was a separate domain. The sample of household was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, at the first sampling stage a specified number of census enumerations areas (EA), was selected systematically with probability proportional to size. A household listing was carried out within the selected enumeration areas, identifying the households with and without children under 5 years. In total, 25 households with and without children under 5 were selected in each sample enumeration area through systematic random sampling method. To ensure strong representativeness of children under 5 in the sample, household with children under 5 were oversampled. Where 13 households with children under 5 and 12 households without were selected from listing in each enumeration area. A total sample of 512 enumeration area and 12800 households was selected for the survey. As the sample is not self-weighting, sample weights are used for reporting survey results.

The sampling frame of Nepal is based on the 2011 National population and Housing Census (NPHC). The census frame is a complete list of all census wards created for the 2011 NPHC. At the time of last census, the urban household population constituted 20% of the total household population. According to the latest changes in the administrative structure, following the federalization of the government, the urban household population increased to 65%. CBS updated the population frame to reflect the current status. In designing the sample for the Nepal MICS, it was very useful to review the sample design and results of the MICS conducted in 2014, documented in the Final Report of that survey.

Therefore, a multi-stage, stratified cluster sampling approach was used for the selection of the survey sample. The primary sampling units (PSUs) selected at the first stage were the enumeration areas (EAs) defined for the census enumeration. A listing of households was conducted in each sample enumeration area, and a sample of households was selected at the second stage.

The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.
3-7-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
3-7-1.RATIONALE: To assess overall levels of coverage of family planning programmes and services, the indicator proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15-49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern method is very useful. Access to and use of an effective means to prevent pregnancy helps enable women and their partners to exercise their rights to decide freely and responsibly the number and spacing of their children and to have the information, education and means to do so. Meeting demand for family planning with modern methods also contributes to maternal and child health by preventing unintended pregnancies and closely spaced pregnancies, which are at higher risk for poor obstetrical outcomes. Levels of demand for family planning satisfied with modern methods of 75 per cent or more are generally considered high, and values of 50 per cent or less are generally considered as very low.
3-7-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on women who are currently using a modern method of contraception and number of women using any method of contraception or are having an unmet need for family planning. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.
3-7-1.DATA_COMP:
The numerator is the percentage of women of reproductive age (15-49 years old) who are currently using, or whose partner is currently using, at least one modern contraceptive method. The denominator is the total demand for family planning (the sum of contraceptive prevalence (any method) and the unmet need for family planning).

Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15-49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods = Number of women who are currently using a modern of contraception /Number of women who are using any method of contraception or are having an unmet need for family planning ×100
3-7-1.DATA_VALIDATION:
Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.
3-7-1.DOC_METHOD: It follows the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF.
3-7-1.QUALITY_MGMNT: Central Bureau of Statistics is the official agency to conducts survey and census. It has trained manpower
3-7-1.QUALITY_ASSURE:
The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.

Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.
3-7-1.QUALITY_ASSMNT:
The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.

Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.

1-4-1.SDG_GOAL: 1 End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1-4-1.SDG_TARGET: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.
1-4-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 1.4.1 Use of basic sanitation services – Population using improved sanitation services
1-4-1.SDG_RELATED_INDICATORS: SDG targets relating to sanitation aims to achieve universal access to basic services (SDG 1.4) and universal access to safely managed services (SDG 6.2).
1-4-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
This indicator shows the percentage of population using improved sanitation facilities which are not shared).

According to the Joint Monitoring Program (JMP) of UNICEF and WHO, an improved sanitation facility is defined as one that hygienically separates human excreta from human contact. The sanitation facilities are not considered improved when it is shared with other households or open for public uses. Following classification are used for improved sanitation facilities:

  1. Flush or pour-flush to
  2. Piped sewer system
  3. Septic tank
  4. Pit latrine
  5. Ventilated improved pit (VIP) latrine
  6. Pit toilet with slab and lid
  7. Composing toile (eco-scan)

Therefore, the indicator “Use of basic sanitation services – improved sanitation services” shows the proportion of population using improved sanitation services in a country. For example, according to MICS Nepal 2019, 93.8% of population are using improved sanitation facilities in Nepal.
1-4-1.SOURCE_TYPE: An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.

A listing of households was conducted in each sample enumeration area, and a sample of households was selected at the second stage.

The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.
1-4-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
1-4-1.RATIONALE: The indicator “Use of basic sanitation services – improved sanitation services” shows the proportion of population using improved sanitation services in a country. To avoid adverse health effects of poor sanitation, access to basic sanitation is a fundamental need. It documented the health and economic benefits of improved sanitation facilities to households and individuals. Use of an improved sanitation facility is a proxy for the use of basic sanitation. Furthermore, it helps to target and plan efforts to improve access to sanitation and to monitor progress of such measures.
1-4-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on population using improved sanitation facilities and number of household members. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.
1-4-1.DATA_COMP:
Use of basic sanitation services – Population using improved sanitation facilities = Number of people who use an improved sanitation/Number of household members×100

The indicator is computed as the ratio of the number of people who use an improved sanitation facility expressed as percentage.

Use of basic sanitation services – Population using improved sanitation facilities = Improved sanitation facilities [Flush/Pour flush to (Piped sewer system+ Septic tank+ Pit latrine+ others)+ Ventilated improved pit latrine + Pit latrine with slab+ Composting toilet] used by population/ Number of household members×100

3-2-1.SDG_GOAL: 3 Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-2-1.SDG_TARGET: 3.1 By 2030, end preventable deaths of new-borns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births
3-2-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
According to WHO, under age 5 mortality rate is defined as the probability of a child born in a given year dying before reaching their fifth birthday and expressed per 1000 live birth.

According to United Nations Principles and Recommendations for a Vital Statistics System live birth is defined as the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception, irrespective of the duration of pregnancy, which after such separation breathes or shows any other evidence of life such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord, definite movement of voluntary muscles, whether or not the umbilical cord has been cut or the placenta is attached; each product of such a birth is considered as live-born regardless of gestational age.

Death is permanent is the permanent disappearance of all evidence of life at any time after live birth has taken place (post-natal cessation of vital functions without capability of resuscitation)

Under-five mortality captures the effect of gender discrimination better than infant mortality does, as malnutrition and medical interventions have more significant impacts to this age group. If female under-five mortality is higher, girls are likely to have less access to resources than boys.

The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. 3-2-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
3-2-1.RATIONALE: Child survival is measured by under-five mortality rate. Also, it reflects the social, economic and environment conditions in which (and others in society) live, including their health care. Because data on the incidences and prevalence of disease (morbidity data) frequently are unavailable, mortality rates are often used to identify vulnerable populations. Furthermore, it also helps to measure the access of children and communities to basic health intervention such as vaccination, medical treatment of infectious disease and adequate nutrition.
3-2-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on total deaths of children under 5 years and total live births in given period of time. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.
3-2-1.DATA_COMP:
This indicators is calculated by dividing the total number deaths of children under 5 years by the total number of live births in the same period multiplied by 1000.

Under 5 mortality rate = Number of deaths of children under 5 years in given period of time /Total number live births in given period of time×1000

3-8-1.SDG_GOAL: 3 Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-8-1.SDG_TARGET: 3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all
3-8-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 3.8.1 Coverage of essential health services (defined as the average coverage of essential services based on tracer interventions that include reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health, infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases and service capacity and access, among the general and the most disadvantaged population)
3-8-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
This indicator shows the percentage of children under age 5 with ARI symptoms in the last 2 weeks for whom advice or treatment was sought from a health facility or provider.

ARI stands for ‘acute respiratory infection’. The definition of ARI used in the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and in the Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS) was chosen by the group and is based on mothers’ perceptions of a child who has a cough, is breathing faster than usual with short, quick breaths or is having difficulty breathing, excluding children that had only a blocked nose.

It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili and were pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. 3-8-1.RATIONALE: Appropriate care of the sick child is defined as providers that can correctly diagnose and treat pneumonia. The proportion of under-fives with ARI that are taken to an appropriate health-care provider is therefore a key indicator for coverage of intervention and care-seeking, and provides critical inputs to the monitoring of progress towards child survival-related Millennium Development Goals and Strategies.
3-8-1.REC_USE_LIM: The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.
3-8-1.DATA_COMP:
This indicators is calculated by dividing the total number of children aged under 5 years with ARI system by the total number of children aged under 5 years multiplied by 100.

Children under age 5 with ARI symptoms = Children aged under 5 years with ARI symptoms/ Total number of children aged under 5 years×100

5-b-1.SDG_GOAL: 5 Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls
5-b-1.SDG_TARGET: 5.b Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women
5-b-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 5.b.1 Proportion of individuals who own a mobile telephone, by sex
5-b-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
This indicator is defined as the percentage of women and men age 15-49 years who own a mobile phone.

An individual owns a mobile cellular phone if he/she has a mobile cellular phone device with at least one active SIM card for personal use. Mobile cellular phones supplied by employers that can be used for personal reasons (to make personal calls, access the Internet, etc.) are included. Individuals who have only active SIM card(s) and not a mobile phone device are excluded. Individuals who have a mobile phone for personal use that is not registered under his/her name are also included. An active SIM card is a SIM card that has been used in the last three months.

A mobile (cellular) telephone refers to a portable telephone subscribing to a public mobile telephone service using cellular technology, which provides access to the PSTN. This includes analogue and digital cellular systems and technologies such as IMT-2000 (3G) and IMT-Advanced. Users of both post-paid subscriptions and prepaid accounts are included.
5-b-1.SOURCE_TYPE: An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.
5-b-1.COLL_METHOD:
The sample for the Nepal MICS 2019 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas and seven provinces. The urban and rural areas within each province were identified as the main sampling strata. Kathmandu valley urban is included as a separate stratum as it’s characteristics differ from the rest. Each stratum was a separate domain. The sample of household was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, at the first sampling stage a specified number of census enumerations areas (EA), was selected systematically with probability proportional to size. A household listing was carried out within the selected enumeration areas, identifying the households with and without children under 5 years. In total, 25 households with and without children under 5 years were selected in each sample enumeration area through systematic random sampling method. To ensure strong representativeness of children under 5 in the sample, household with children under 5 years were oversampled. Hence, 13 households with children under 5 years and 12 households without children under 5 years were selected from listing in each enumeration area. A total sample of 512 enumeration area and 12800 households was selected for the survey. As the sample is not self-weighting, sample weights are used for reporting survey results.

The sampling frame of Nepal is based on the 2011 National population and Housing Census (NPHC). The census frame is a complete list of all census wards created for the 2011 NPHC. At the time of last census, the urban household population constituted 20% of the total household population. According to the latest changes in the administrative structure, following the federalization of the government, the urban household population increased to 65%. CBS updated the population frame to reflect the current status. In designing the sample for the Nepal MICS, it was very useful to review the sample design and results of the MICS conducted in 2014, documented in the final report of that survey.

Therefore, a multi-stage, stratified cluster sampling approach was used for the selection of the survey sample. The primary sampling units (PSUs) selected at the first stage were the enumeration areas (EAs) defined for the census enumeration. A listing of households was conducted in each sample enumeration area, and a sample of households was selected at the second stage.

The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.
5-b-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
5-b-1.RATIONALE: Mobile phone networks have spread rapidly over the last decade and the number of mobile-cellular subscriptions is quasi equal to the number of the people living on earth. However, not every person uses, or owns a mobile-cellular telephone. Mobile phone ownership, in particular, is important to track gender equality since the mobile phone is a personal device that, if owned and not just shared, provides women with a degree of independence and autonomy, including for professional purposes.
5-b-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on total number of in-scope individuals who own a mobile phone and total number of in-scope individuals. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.
5-b-1.DATA_COMP:
This indicator is calculated by dividing the total number of in-scope individuals who own a mobile phone by the total number of in-scope individuals.

Proportion of individuals who own a mobile telephone, by sex = Number of individuals (15-49 years) who own a personal mobile phone / Total number of people aged between 15 to 49 years ×100
5-b-1.DATA_VALIDATION:
Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.

16-9-1.SDG_GOAL: 16 Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels
16-9-1.SDG_TARGET: 16.9 By 2030, provide legal identity for all, including birth registration
16-9-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 16.9.1 Proportion of children under 5 years of age whose births have been registered with a civil authority, by age
16-9-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
This indicator shows proportion of children under the 5 years of age whose birth have been registered with a civil authority.)

Every child has right to name and nationality ensured by the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) and other international treaties. To secure recognition before the law, safeguard rights and ensure that any violation of these rights does not go unnoticed, the first step crucial step is to register children at birth.

Based on Birth, Death and Other Personal Incident Act 1976 and the Birth, Death and Other Personal Incident Regulations 1977, Nepal has had a civil (vital) registration programme since 1977. Birth registration.

Birth certificates are proof of registration and the first form of legal identity and are often required to access health care or education.

Birth registration is defined as the continuous, permanent and universal recording, within the civil registry, of the occurrence and characteristics of births in accordance with the legal requirements of a country.

16-9-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
16-9-1.RATIONALE:
The indicator “Percentage of children under age 5 whose birth is registered with a civil authority” is to ensure the fulfilment of child rights.

Starting point for the recognition and protection of every person’s right to identity and existence is birth registration. Failure to register births either due to insufficient administrative systems, discrimination, or isolation is a key cause of social exclusion. In Nepal, children are more likely to be registered closer to their entry into school at five years of age. A birth certificate is must for school enrolment. However, the legal requirements is to register new-borns within 35 days of birth. By ensuring registration of all births, it will increase population’s opportunities to access services and opportunities.
16-9-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on number of births registered within a given period of time after birth in a given calendar year and total number of births in a given calendar year. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.

Proportion of children under 5 years of age whose births have been registered with a civil authority, by age = Number of children under age of five whose births /Total number of children under the age of five in the population×100

Number of children under age of five whose births are reported as being registered with the relevant national civil authorities divided by the total number of children under the age of five in the population multiplied by 100.

3-a-1.SDG_GOAL: 3 Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-a-1.SDG_TARGET: 3.a Strengthen the implementation of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control in all countries, as appropriate
3-a-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 3.a.1 Age-standardized prevalence of current tobacco use among persons aged 15 years and older
3-a-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
The indicator is defined as the percentage of the population aged 15 years and over who currently use any tobacco product (smoked and/or smokeless tobacco) on a daily or non-daily basis.

Use of smoked and/or smokeless tobacco products is known as tobacco use.

“Current use” means use of tobacco product within the previous 30 days at the time of survey, whether daily or non-daily use.

“Smoked tobacco products” include cigarettes, cigarillos, cigars, cheroots, bidis, pipes, shisha (water pipes), roll-your-own tobacco, kretek and any other form of tobacco that is consumed by smoking.

“Smokeless tobacco product” includes moist snuff, creamy snuff, dry snuff, plug, dissolvable, gul, loose leaf, red tooth powder, snus, chimo, guthkha, khaini, gudakhu, zarda, quiman, dohra, tuibur, nasway, naas, naswar, shammah, toombak, paan (betel quid with tobacco), iq’mink, mishri, tapkeer, tombol and any other tobacco product that consumed by sniffing, holding in the mouth or chewing.

3-a-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
3-a-1.RATIONALE: The products made up of entirely of partly from the leaf of tobacco as raw materials, which are intended to be smoked, sucked, chewed, or snuffed and contained highly addictive psychoactive ingredient, nicotine are known as tobacco products. Use of tobacco products lead to chronic disease and death. There is no proven safe level of tobacco use or of second-hand smoke exposure. All daily and non-daily users of tobacco are at risk of a variety of poor health outcomes across the life-course including chronic illness. Reducing the prevalence of current tobacco use will make a large contribution to reducing premature mortality from non-communicable disease.
3-a-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on total numbers of daily and non-daily users of tobacco from the age group 15-49 years and total number of men and women age 15-49 years. 16-2-1.SDG_GOAL: 16 Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels
16-2-1.SDG_TARGET: 16.2.1 End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children
16-2-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 16.2.1.1 Children age 1-14 years who experienced psychological aggression or physical punishment during the last one month) (%)
16-2-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
This indicator shows the percentage of children aged between 1 to 14 years experienced psychological aggression and / or physical punishment during the last one month).

The process of teaching child acceptable behaviors and self-control is child discipline. Providing guidance on handling emotions or conflicts in such manners that encourage judgement and responsibility as well as preserve children’s self – esteem, physical and psychological integrity and dignity is a practice of positive parenting. However, caregiver rely on punitive methods to obtain desired behaviors from children too often. Consequently, it inflict short-term and long term harm such as poorer quality of parent-child relationships, mental health problems (such as depression), increased child aggression, antisocial behavior and lower intellectual achievement.

According to WHO, psychological aggression refers to the action of shouting, yelling or screaming at a child, as well as calling a child offensive names, such as ‘dumb’ or ‘lazy’. With the action intended to cause physical pain or discomfort, but not an injuries is known as physical punishment.

16-2-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
16-2-1.RATIONALE: The indicator “Children age 1-14 years who experienced psychological aggression or physical punishment during the last one month) (%)” is defined as the proportion of children aged 1-114 years who experienced any physical punishment and/or psychological aggression by caregivers in the past one month. Child discipline is integral part of raising children. However, the use of physical force or verbal intimidation is not only a violation of children’s rights but has been shown to inflict short and long term harmful consequences. Furthermore, it may carry forward into their adult life.
16-2-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on children aged 1-14 years who experienced psychological aggression or physical punishment and number of children age 1-14 years. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.
16-2-1.DATA_COMP:
Children age 1-14 years who experienced psychological aggression or physical punishment during the last one month = Children between the age group 1-14 years who experience psychological aggression and/or physical punishment /Total number of children aged between 1-14 years×100

The indicator is computed as the ratio of children age 1-14 years who experienced psychological aggression and/or physical punishment expressed as percentage.

Hitting and slapping on the face, head or ears, Beating up, that is, hit over and over as hard one could are the severe punishment measured by the indicator.

1-3-1.SDG_GOAL: 1 End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1-3-1.SDG_TARGET: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.
1-3-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 1.3.1 Proportion of population covered by social protection floors/systems, by sex, distinguishing children, unemployed persons, older persons, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, newborns, work-injury victims and the poor and the vulnerable
1-3-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
This indicator shows the percentage of household members living in households that received any type of social transfers and benefits in the last 3 months.

Social protection is a set of policies and programs that helps to tackle poverty, deprivation and destitution of common people throughout their life-course. It aims to support vulnerable people like helpless single women, widows, single parents, disaster victims, disabled people, children, destitute people and orphans. According to UNICEF, increasing volatility at the macro and household level, the existing inequalities and exclusion, threats posed to sustainable development goals by climate change and changing population trends have heightened the relevance and political momentum for social protection globally.


Social transfers refer to cash or in-kind (food or non-food items) transfers from the state to the beneficiary. It could be either conditional or unconditional depending upon an action. Monthly cash allowances to most vulnerable populations, scholarships to students, education materials, food and housing supports, health insurance subsidies to families living in poverty, cash or in kind transfers to unemployed, or any other types of ad-hoc support, excluding transfers or assistance from family members are kinds of social transfers found in Nepal.
1-3-1.SOURCE_TYPE: An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.
1-3-1.COLL_METHOD:
The sample for the Nepal MICS 2019 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas and seven provinces. The urban and rural areas within each province were identified as the main sampling strata. Kathmandu valley urban is included as a separate stratum as it’s characteristics differ from the rest. Each stratum was a separate domain. The sample of household was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, at the first sampling stage a specified number of census enumerations areas (EA), was selected systematically with probability proportional to size. A household listing was carried out within the selected enumeration areas, identifying the households with and without children under 5 years. In total, 25 households with and without children under 5 were selected in each sample enumeration area through systematic random sampling method. To ensure strong representativeness of children under 5 in the sample, household with children under 5 were oversampled. Where 13 households with children under 5 and 12 households without were selected from listing in each enumeration area. A total sample of 512 enumeration area and 12800 households was selected for the survey. As the sample is not self-weighting, sample weights are used for reporting survey results.

The sampling frame of Nepal is based on the 2011 National population and Housing Census (NPHC). The census frame is a complete list of all census wards created for the 2011 NPHC. At the time of last census, the urban household population constituted 20% of the total household population. According to the latest changes in the administrative structure, following the federalization of the government, the urban household population increased to 65%. CBS updated the population frame to reflect the current status. In designing the sample for the Nepal MICS, it was very useful to review the sample design and results of the MICS conducted in 2014, documented in the Final Report of that survey.

Therefore, a multi-stage, stratified cluster sampling approach was used for the selection of the survey sample. The primary sampling units (PSUs) selected at the first stage were the enumeration areas (EAs) defined for the census enumeration. A listing of households was conducted in each sample enumeration area, and a sample of households was selected at the second stage.

The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.
1-3-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
1-3-1.RATIONALE: Population covered by social transfers measures the direct and indirect beneficiaries who are actually receiving social protection at the time by household members. It can evaluate existing situation and support in policy making and planning, implementation and budgetary synergies between demand-side and supply-side interventions to improve the schemes of social transfers effective.
1-3-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on number of household members living in households receiving specific types of support in the last 3 months. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.
1-3-1.DATA_COMP:
Proportion of population covered by social protection floors/systems, by sex, distinguishing children, unemployed persons, older persons, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, newborns, work-injury victims and the poor and the vulnerable in last 3 months = Household members living in households that received social transfers or benefits/Number of household members×100

The indicator, proportion of population covered by social protection floors/systems, by sex, distinguishing children, unemployed persons, older persons, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, newborns, work-injury victims and the poor and the vulnerable is calculated by adding all the social transfers or benefits and divided by total household members. It excluded transfers or assistance from family, relatives and neighbors.

Proportion of population covered by social protection floors/systems, by sex, distinguishing children, unemployed persons, older persons, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, newborns, work-injury victims and the poor and the vulnerable = Household members living in households that received social transfers or benefits (Senior Citizen Allowance + Single Women Allowance+ Widow Allowance+ Any Retirement Pension+ Child Grant+ Disabled Allowance+ Minority/ Indigenous Allowance+ Any other external assistance program)/ Number of household members.
1-3-1.DATA_VALIDATION:
Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.
1-3-1.DOC_METHOD: It follows the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF.
1-3-1.QUALITY_MGMNT: Central Bureau of Statistics is the official agency to conducts survey and census. It has trained manpower

Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.

Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.
1-3-1.QUALITY_ASSMNT:
The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.

Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.
1-3-1.COVERAGE: The data is available by province and rural and urban. Furthermore, it is disaggregated by types of social transfers also.
1-3-1.COMPARABILITY: It follows MICS 6 guidelines of UNICEF and can be compared across countries.

5-3-1.SDG_GOAL: 5 Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls
5-3-1.SDG_TARGET: 5.3 Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation
5-3-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 5.3.1 Proportion of women aged 20-24 years who were married or in a union before age 15
5-3-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
This indicator is defined as the percentage of women and men age 20-24 years who were first married or in union before age 15.

According to UNICEF, child marriage is defined as a marriage of a girl or boy before the age of 18 years. It includes both types of union i.e. formal union (marriage) and informal union. Informal unions means couple living together for some time, intends to have a lasting relationship, but do not have formal civil or religious ceremony.

5-3-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
5-3-1.RATIONALE: It is fundamental violation of human rights if there is marriage of a girl or boy before the age of 18. Child marriage forced to a boy or/and girl to take place of adults accompanied by the responsibilities, which they may not be prepared. It often compromises a girl’s development by resulting in early pregnancy and social isolation, interrupting her schooling, limiting her opportunities for career and vocational advancement and placing her at increased risk of intimate partner violence. In many cultures, girls reaching puberty are expected to assume gender roles associated with womanhood. These include entering a union and becoming a mother. The practice of early/child marriage is a direct manifestation of gender inequality. The issue of child marriage is addressed in a number of international conventions and agreements. Although marriage is not mentioned directly in the Convention on the Rights of the Child, child marriage is linked to other rights – such as the right to freedom of expression, the right to protection from all forms of abuse, and the right to be protected from harmful traditional practices.
5-3-1.REC_USE_LIM: The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on number of women aged 20-24 years who were married or in union before age 15 and total number of women aged 20-24 years in the population. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.
5-3-1.DATA_COMP:
Number of women aged 20-24 who were first married or in union before age 15 divided by the total number of women aged 20-24 in the population multiplied by 100.

Proportion of women aged 20-24 years who were married or in a union before age 15 = Number of women aged 20-24 who were first married or in union before age 15 / Total number of women aged 20-24 years in the population ×100

4-1-1.SDG_GOAL: 4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-1-1.SDG_TARGET: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes
4-1-1.SDG_INDICATOR: 4.1.1 Proportion of children and young people: (a) in grades 2/3; (b) at the end of primary; and (c) at the end of lower secondary achieving at least a minimum proficiency level in (i) reading and (ii) mathematics, by sex
4-1-1.STAT_CONC_DEF:
This indicator is defined as the percentage of children who successfully completed four foundational number tasks

(d) Age 7-14.

One of the most fundamental skills that a child can learn is the ability to read and understand the simple text. Learning outcomes are key indicators of quality education as they provide evidence on whether schools are equipping children with the foundational learning skills. Therefore, this indicator helps to measure learning outcomes expected for grades 2 and 3 in numeracy and reading among a children.

A strong foundation in basic numeracy skills during the early grades is crucial for success in mathematics in the later years. At present, mathematical skills are must require skills for all sorts of competitive job. According to report “School Readiness and Later Achievement’, early mathematical knowledge is a primary predictor of later academic achievement and future success in mathematics. It is related to an early and strong conceptual function. Foundational skills are divided into four tasks:

  1. Number reading
  2. Number discrimination
  3. Addition
  4. Pattern recognition

If the child succeeds in all four tasks above mentioned, s/he is considered to have foundational numeracy skills.
4-1-1.SOURCE_TYPE: An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.

4-1-1.INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
4-1-1.RATIONALE: Over the past decades, access to education increased significantly. However, the disparities remain and many children in school struggle to achieve basic literacy and numeracy skills. Learning outcomes are key indicators of quality education as they provide evidence on whether schools are equipping children with the foundational learning skills. Therefore, this indicator helps to measure learning outcomes in numeracy and reading among children. It helps to capture a fuller picture of learning outcomes of children, including the disadvantaged, which helps ministries of education target support for children not learning to their potential.
4-1-1.REC_USE_LIM:
A small proportion of interviewers across early MICS6 surveys in Nepal and elsewhere recorded the results of the two practise items in the data collection application, effectively shifting the responses in numeracy foundational skills questionnaire two spaces. During secondary editing such cases were identified and shifted back to the correct position, but the consequences remained of the loss of answers to the last two of the five pattern recognition items. The module has now been redesigned to avoid the occurrence of this problem.

While producing this report, several options were considered for presentation of the findings:

  1. Use all children in the table in MICS report. This would the best possible estimates on the tasks of number reading, number discrimination and addition, but underestimate on pattern recognition and, most importantly on the overall indicator of foundational numeracy skills.
  2. Exclude children affected by the shifted entries. This would impact all results in the tables, but the extent of the impact would need further analysis and depends largely on the amount and distribution of the excluded cases.
  3. Use a mixed approach, presenting number reading, number discrimination and addition for all children and the pattern recognition and overall indicator only on children not affected by the shifted entries, effectively using two denominators in the table.
  4. Not presenting the table and indicator as per methodology, reducing the requirement of successful completion in pattern recognition to three items rather than five. This would overestimate pattern recognition and the overall indicator compared to standard methodology.

Following analysis of the extent and distribution of shifted cases, option 2) was selected as score distributions of first three items of pattern recognition are very similar across shifted and non-shifted samples which indicates that excluding shifted cases would not affect overall average while addressing biases introduced by shifted cases.
4-1-1.DATA_COMP:
Where,

FNSng = the share of children aged n and attending school grade g who have foundational numeracy skills

Numbskillng = children aged n and attending school grade g who have foundational numeracy skills equal to 1 according to the formula above

Tng­= total number of children aged n and attending school grade g

Proportion of children aged n years and attending school grade g who have foundational numeracy skills = Number of children aged n years and attending school grade g who have number skill equal to 1 according to the formula above / Total number of children aged n years and attending school grade g ×100
